title: Hasegawa Yoshimichi
text:
Count was a <a href="Field%20Marshal%20%28Japan%29">field marshal</a> in the <a href="Imperial%20Japanese%20Army">Imperial Japanese Army</a> and <a href="Japanese%20Governor%20General%20of%20Korea">Japanese Governor General of Korea</a> from 1916 to 1919. His Japanese decorations included <a href="Order%20of%20the%20Golden%20Kite">Order of the Golden Kite</a> (1st class) and <a href="Order%20of%20the%20Chrysanthemum">Order of the Chrysanthemum</a>.
Biography.
Hasegawa was born as the son of a <a href="samurai">samurai</a> <a href="kenjutsu">fencing</a> master in the <a href="Iwakuni">Iwakuni</a> sub-fief of <a href="Nagato%20Province">Chōshū</a> (present-day <a href="Yamaguchi%20Prefecture">Yamaguchi Prefecture</a>), Hasegawa served under the Chōshū forces during the <a href="Boshin%20War">Boshin War</a> from January until March 1868 during the <a href="Meiji%20Restoration">Meiji Restoration</a> which overthrew the <a href="Tokugawa%20shogunate">Tokugawa shogunate</a>.
Upon the formation of the <a href="Imperial%20Japanese%20Army">Imperial Japanese Army</a> in 1871, Hasegawa was commissioned a <a href="Captain%20%28land%20and%20air%29">captain</a>. Later, as a <a href="major">major</a>, he was given command of a <a href="regiment">regiment</a> during the <a href="Satsuma%20Rebellion">Satsuma Rebellion</a>, and saw action at the relief of <a href="Kumamoto%20Castle">Kumamoto Castle</a> on 14 April 1877.
He traveled to <a href="France">France</a> as <a href="military%20attach%C3%A9">military attaché</a> in 1885 to study European <a href="military%20strategy">military strategy</a>, <a href="military%20tactics">military tactics</a> and equipment. Upon his return to Japan the following year, Hasegawa was promoted to <a href="major%20general">major general</a>.
During the <a href="First%20Sino-Japanese%20War">First Sino-Japanese War</a>, Hasegawa won distinction for valor on behalf of his 12th Infantry Brigade at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Pyongyang%20%281894%29">Battle of Pyongyang</a> on 15 September 1894 and in skirmishes around <a href="Haicheng%2C%20Liaoning">Haicheng</a> from December 1894 until January 1895. After the war, he was ennobled with the title of "danshaku" (<a href="baron">baron</a>) under the "<a href="kazoku">kazoku</a>" peerage system.
During the <a href="Russo-Japanese%20War">Russo-Japanese War</a>, Hasegawa was assigned to the <a href="Japanese%20First%20Army">First Army</a> under General <a href="Kuroki%20Tamemoto">Kuroki Tamemoto</a> as commander of the <a href="Imperial%20Guard%20of%20Japan">Imperial Guards Division</a> in the spring of 1904. He later fought with distinction at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Yalu%20River%20%281904%29">Battle of the Yalu</a> on 30 April – 1 May 1904, and was soon after promoted to <a href="general">general</a> in June 1904.
He was commander of the <a href="Chosen%20Army">Korea Garrison Army</a> from September 1904 until December 1908. In 1907, Hasegawa was elevated to the title of "shishaku" (<a href="viscount">viscount</a>). Hasegawa was appointed <a href="Chief%20of%20Staff">Chief of Staff</a> of the <a href="Imperial%20Japanese%20Army%20General%20Staff">Imperial Japanese Army General Staff</a> in 1912. He forced <a href="Ministry%20of%20War%20of%20Japan">War Minister</a> <a href="Uehara%20Y%C5%ABsaku">Uehara Yūsaku</a> to resign over <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Japan">Prime Minister</a> <a href="Saionji%20Kinmochi">Saionji Kinmochi</a>'s tight fiscal policy and attempted revision of the system whereby only active duty officers would be able to serve as Ministers of War and Navy. The collapse of Saionji’s government was known as the "Taishō Political Crisis".
In 1915, Hasegawa was awarded the title of <a href="Field%20Marshal%20%28Japan%29">field marshal</a>, and was elevated to the title of "hakushaku" (<a href="count">count</a>) in 1916. From October 1916, he served as the second <a href="Japanese%20Governor-General%20of%20Korea">Japanese Governor-General of Korea</a>, and was later criticized for his military approach to the <a href="March%201st%20Movement">Samil Independence Movement</a>.
Hasegawa died in 1924. His grave is at <a href="Aoyama%20Cemetery">Aoyama Cemetery</a> in <a href="Aoyama%2C%20Minato%2C%20Tokyo">Aoyama</a>, <a href="Minato%2C%20Tokyo">Minato</a>, <a href="Tokyo">Tokyo</a>.
